direction.raw_text: Paramedics swarm over Stephen as the ambulance screams through the night. Brian's right there, holding his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His brother squeezes Brian's hand, his eyes never leaving him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stephen's EKG's begun to falter. The other paramedic fires off an injection into his IV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The EKG's become erratic. Stephen's eyes never leave Brian's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They put an ambo bag over Stephen's face. The eyes never leave Brian's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're breathing for him now. The EKG begins shrieking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The paramedics begin scrambling to load the defibrillator pads on Stephen's chest. But the fireman's eyes never waver from Brian. They look into his with complete conviction, complete acceptance, And then they don't.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't tell them about Adcox... Don't let 'em...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry... I'm sorry I thought... I won't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reading EKG) Oh shit, give him some lidocaine, now. Now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) Who's your brother?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His pressure's fading -- push some adrenalin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh man, don't you die... Don't you die...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 He's going south... He's gonna box damn it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goddamn it don't you die now... Not now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: V-fib!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : Then, FADE UP TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A silent, quiet street absolutely empty of traffic. Then over the crest of Chicago's mightiest thoroughfare, creeps slowly a fire engine. It's emergency lights are on but not the siren. This engine isn't in a hurry today. Behind comes another fire engine. And another. Ten, twenty, all of them creeping slowly along. And behind the engines now walk firemen in their dress blues. Hundreds of them. Walking silently in step behind
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Loaded in the rear of Engine 17. Santos drives as Grindle, Brian, and the men of ladder company 46, walk behind. The silent procession passes under extended aerial ladders crossed like dress swords. Average people stop, take their hats off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two coffins, lying side by side, draped in the blue and white of the Chicago flag. A single fire helmet rests atop each casket. Brian stands at attention beside Helen. He holds the hand of Stephen's son Sean, his eyes clouded with tears as a fire dept. honor guard plays Taps. Jennifer's there, too far away to touch. Rimgale, still wearing a head bandage, stands stiffly beside a brass bell and speaks with a voice raw and weary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a small hammer Rimgale rings out 3-3-5 on the bell. The honor guard folds the flag covering Stephen's casket and hands it to Helen, who holds it to her breast as we
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: In the Chicago Fire Department the alarm code 3-3-5 signifies that the company has returned home to quarters. We will now ring out that code to welcome home John Adcox and Stephen McCaffrey...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A sea of blue uniforms drifting across green as the funeral breaks up. Brian hugs Helen and Sean. Lets them go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rimgale's there, resting against his dept. sedan as Brian walks by, pauses, and leans on it beside him. A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rimgale turns to walk back to his sedan. He pauses. Looks back to Brian.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Your brother was a good man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Another couple of good men get burned up for their city? Is that how it's going to read? (Brian doesn't answer) You're the only one that knows.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like it never happened...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Want to help me with something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: An elevator opens as Brian and Rimgale walk quickly out, down a hall, and BURST into Swayzak's office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Alderman's there, giving a press conference from his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rimgale sits on Swayzak's desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rimgale drops the manning report on Swayzak's desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The room explodes with questions. Through the din Brian leans over the desk very close to Swayzak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brian turns and pushes his way out. At the door he pauses and looks back at Rimgale. The investigator nods and smiles just a little...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Swayzak! How ya doin'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (confused) Investigator...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a little busy right now -- SHADOW This'll only take a minute. There's two cops outside that want to ask you about this --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is just a guess of course, but I think they're gonna want to know why you secretly paid Donald Cosgrove, Jeffrey Holcomb and Alan Seagrave to create a phony manpower study. (to cameras) You guys'll wait, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See that glow flashing in the corner of your eye? That's your career dissipation light. And it just went into high gear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Brian walks down it, Rimgale appears and calls to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brian hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And there's just a beat between the investigator and his probie before Brian nods and walks away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Brian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't keep looking over your shoulder for the ghost. It's gone now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Brian walks down the hall. He passes Jennifer's small office. She's in there, surrounded by packing boxes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I think your boss is going to need some spin control.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I quit two days ago, Brian.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) What'll you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't have the slightest idea...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll see ya around, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a small town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: And morning breaking across the avenues and up against the tired brick of firehouse 17.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brian sits staring into his locker, lost in thought, his equipment stacked up on the bench beside him. THE ALARM KLAXON SOUNDS INT. FIRE STATION 17 - APPARATUS FLOOR And firemen scurrying to their equipment on the apparatus floor. They're climbing aboard their rigs now and the pumper's diesel is coughing to life. At the last moment, as it begins to pull out, Brian comes sliding down the pole in his turn-out gear, bounces off the floor, and climbs aboard as the engine WHISTLES away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a new fireman beside him on the bench. He can't get his coat buckled right. Brian leans over does it for him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're doing it wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: And the fire engine slips away from us, down the avenue, into the city as we
direction.name: direction
